Review title: Jerry Maguire, one heck of a film.
Review_body: My all-time favourite film. Partly because it says all that should be said about love without ever becoming "romantic" and secondly because I saw a lot of myself in Jerry Maguire. No, I am not sleeping with a Kelly Preston lookalike, and neither am I in sports entertainment. I saw a guy lose everything he thought was his world and find everything he never had when all else seemed lost. I thinCuba Gooding delivered the performance of a life-time. I have never seen him more in character, before and since. The casting was excellent and the movie feels 'real' and people who have never watched it and have heard me talk about it have been surprised at just how good it is when they actually see it.

I refused to see Jerry Maguire for several years, assuming it was a cheap movie about money, sports and sex. When i finally watched it on TV, i was blown away. This movie is about hope, redemption, love, and finding out the meaning of life. Tom Cruise does a spectacular job playing someone with nothing to loose, and Cuba Gooding's performance brought tears to my eyes. Renee Zellweger fits perfectly by having great chemistry with Jerry, and by having a normal, plain look. This film works because it's so real and easily plausible; its a witty, romantic drama more than a romantic comedy that proves its never too late to start over or take a risk.

Review title: Add a thrill to your personal life.
Review_body: This was a life changing movie for me. While I was disgusted by the first sex scene and the overuse of strong vulgar language in places; I rediscovered what I had lost in my own life. A relationship with that one who is my life time companion needs to be much more than just an existence of being polite to one another. The thought of completing one another just sent thrills up my spine. As a result of this movie, I have been getting deeply involved in her world and her. I didn't tell her about the movie or my motives. She has responded to this new romancing by moving so much closer to me. I have rediscovered that girl that took my heart some years ago But the story line is not only one of romance. I loved the logic in the movie! Watch for a theme of heart in work but not in personal relationships set against the theme of heart in relationship but not in work. Watch for the theme of one lover interested in only herself and her goals while another lover is interested in the loved one's goals. Watch how the loved one responds to each manifestation of each lover's view of him. Tom Cruise's dynamite control over audiences comes out strongly in several situations where he uses, as in every movie I've watched him, his Harvard lawyer alter ego. This added dimension of intellect is what I like most about Tom Cruise. You see him play "thinking on his feet" so well. This sets Tom Cruise over all the other actors. He looks sharp and greatly intelligent without the appearance of being an egghead. The scenes in which he refutes illogic statements and takes command of a living room both with one person or with a whole group are a reminiscent shadow of his brilliant performance in "A Few Good Men". Renee Zellweger's performance was spectacular. I didn't know she existed until now, but I will be sure to watch for her in the future movies that I watch. I also greatly enjoyed Cuba Gooding, Jr.'s portrayal of Rod Tidwell as a warm, but explosively tough football player. I have watched and will watch this movie over and over. I recommend this movie highly to all movie watchers who want to add an extra thrill in their own personal lives.
Tom Cruise is a terrible actor and the story is flat and dumb.

Review title: A beautiful tale of true human emotions.
Review_body: I remember watching Jerry Maguire and being stunned by what I was seeing. The film's premise is a sharply real one which reminds us all of times in our own lives.  Many moments in the film portray events that happen to real people and not a glamourised sugar coated image of life as seen by a Hollywood producer.  The film is clever and touching as well as being made in a highly sophisticated style which after being broken up reveals much more than a simple love story.  The emotions shown are depicted with accuracy and confidence to such an extent that at points you actually forget you are watching a film and you become part of the universe which Cameron Crowe has skilfully created.  These reasons and many more which are too long to place on paper are why I believe this is the greatest film ever made, I urge you to attempt watching it.

Review title: Brilliant take on the Hollywood romance genre
Review_body: Sweet but not overly sentimental,comical yet at times a real tearjerker, are the only words that describe ''Jerry Maguire''. Not since ''American Beauty'' has a film managed to touch me in such a gentle and profound way. While ''Jerry Maguire'' may be the Hollywood fabrication of real life, the brilliant Cameron Crowe is there to insure that it doesn't fall and squirm in the trash can which is usually the case with Hollywood romances. ''Jerry Maguire'' packs even more heart than Crowe's earlier film ''Say Anything...'' and even more attitude than ''Almost Famous''. It's one movie that won't make you go back to the box-office and demand ''Show me the money''.

Review_body: Cameron Crowe beautifully exposes a man whose ideals far exceed his surroundings, and who with the help of those willing to stick out the hard times with him, finds his true self....thats the corny way I describe this story of a superagent left with a mid-level football star (the amazing Cuba Gooding Jr.), a lonely and idealistic single-mother secretary (Renee Zellweger at her best), and her adorable child (Jonathan Lipnicki). Review title: Cheesy, contrived, bloated...but I love it
Review_body: I've seen Jerry Maguire a number of times but it was only on my most recent viewing, at the age of 23, that I came to truly appreciate it. Yes it is all the things I described in the title; but it is also a charming and original film filled with excellent performances, under the control of a man who knows exactly what story he wants to tell. I'm not going to tell everyone it doesn't have its flaws- I can picture Crowe sitting there and smiling to himself after writing "You had me at hello"- but this is anything but a bad film. Jerry Maguire features an unusual central romance, with Cruise and Zellweger's characters getting together more out of convenience than love (on his part anyway). The relationship is handled with maturity and honesty by all involved. Cruise is terrific throughout the whole film but it is his moments with Zellweger and her character's son where he truly shines. Zellweger herself, oft maligned, also puts in a great performance and in my opinion she has never looked lovelier. But it is the relationship between Cruise's Maguire and Oscar winning Cuba Gooding Jr's Rod Tidwell that is the film's real selling point. It's a relationship built on loyalty, trust and friendship. The film has its twists and turns (and it is too long) but it is the bond between agent and star that keeps the film afloat and ultimately gives it a happy ending.Oscar Note: I don't know what the reaction was like at the time but popular opinion nowadays is that Gooding didn't deserve the Oscar. Bill Macy and Ed Norton are often cited as being robbed, and I can't deny that they were excellent in their respective roles, but I believe Gooding to be more than worthy. You'd be hard pressed to find a more electric, entertaining and effective performance in any film.

Review title: Why I Love to Hate Cameron Crowe
Review_body: Sitting alone in my living room on the sunny, yet frigid eve of Easter Sunday 2008 amidst six inches of snow that was dumped upon the Chicagoland suburbs the day before. Fueled by nicotine and caffeine I found myself straightening up my apartment and channel surfing when I happened upon an early morning screening of Jerry Maguire on TNT. That's right Jerry Ma-freakin-Guire. I found myself completely and utterly intrigued and drawn in despite the fact that I've seen this movie somewhere in the vicinity of 10-20 times before, typically on random weekend days on basic cable. First things first, I HATE, capital H through E, Renee Zelwegger and the charm of Tom Cruise died for me somewhere between Top Gun and his ill-conceived notion to pick up where L. Ron Hubbard left off on the proliferation of Scientology tip. And don't sleep on little Jonathon Lipnnicky, the cute little over-sized glasses wearing son of Zelwegger's character in the film, speaking of which, has he gotten arrested for marijuana/cocaine possession yet or fallen into the child-star trap yet? As I digress.Anyway, without even realizing it  it happened  the film had my undivided attention and I became emotionally invested in the subtle intricacies of the dialogue and was provoked to the point of inspiration, which in my humble opinion is truly one of the greatest pleasures on Earthbut to arrive at this point watching Jerry Maguire? What was wrong with me  had I become a softy in my late 20s? I even found myself getting the chills and near-tearing up as the relationship between Jerry (played by Cruise) and Rod Tidwell (Oscar winning performance by Cuba Gooding Jr.) progressed and Jerry left himself emotionally vulnerable, which apparently is atypical of your big shot sports agent in this day and age, only to win back his wife Dorothy (played by Zelwegger) with one of the more memorable lines in recent film history  'you had me at hello'.I then began realizing that despite my anti-Hollywood, screw all major studio releases attitude cultivated sometime between my junior year of high school and becoming a film studies major during my college days in Madison, WI, I did not hate Columbia TriStar or Cruise or Zelwegger or even Cuba (Gooding Jr.  not the home of Fidel Castro people). My hate was centered on Cameron Crowe, the only man with the verbiage and directorial skills to make me give a rat's arse about a movie like Jerry Maguire. The relate-ability of every facet of every relationship and every exchange between these actors that I truly love to hate is so deceivingly obvious and spot-on that I can't help but succumb to the magnetism and emotion of the scenes as they play out. I'm still watching the film and having this epiphany and rather than admit that it's the film I enjoy, I start shaking my head in disbelief amidst teary eyes and thrust all of the recognition and responsibility for the way I'm feeling on Mr. Crowe. I feel vindicated in doing so rather than chalk Jerry Maguire up as another guilty pleasure of mine, kind of like the Hanson song MMMBop. It's then that I decided I needed to write this, if not for the therapeutic function that it's currently providing me, but more so because I feel I owe it to Mr. Crowe.I'm a proud purveyor of classics like Fast Times at Ridgemont High (granted Amy Heckerling directed it), Say Anything and Almost Famous. I'm still trying to be half the man Lloyd Dobbler was in courting (pun intended) Diane Court and churning out 'In Your Eyes' through his ghetto blaster and longed to have experienced the 70s rock scene like William Miller in Almost Famous. Those films equally capture me emotionally, spiritually, have terrific soundtracks and when mixed together in only the way Cameron Crowe can - they inspire me to believe that possibilities are limitless and that anything can happen and eventually, will happen. And when they do, they'll inevitably involve me getting with the perfect girl amidst the backdrop of the perfect song to capture the all-encompassing essence of purity, honesty and lovewhether it is for Diane Court, Stillwater or Dorothy BoydAnd that is why I love to hate, but really just plain admire Mr. Cameron Crowe  or maybe I just enjoy his films. Either way, I think I made my some kind of point, right?

Jerry Maguire is one of my favorite movies of all time. This movie stars Tom Cruise, Renee Zellwegger, and Cuba Gooding Jr in one of their best performances on screen. Jerry Maguire is about a sports agent who one night realizes that he is ashamed of his life, and types a mission statement about the future of the company he works for. That mission statement gets him fired, and changes his life forever. Dorothy Boyd is a single mother, who is an accountant for the company. When Jerry gets fired, she leaves the job with him. After Jerry gets fired, he is only left with one client. This clients name is Ron Tidwell. Dorothy and Ron make Jerry a better person. This movie provided many touching moments, and had a lot of laughs. This movie basically kicked off Zellwegger's career, and it is a movie which in my book is a must see.
